Fields.DialogueText: Everyone, listen to me for a moment.
Our supply rooms have grown especially disorganized recently and are all in need of some help. I know it's no one's favorite job, but...
I'd be happy to help, Kapitän!

Fields.MenuText: Wonderful! Thank for you for your help, Nürnberg.
Well, I admire your enthusiasm.
Why are you this excited to work in the supply rooms? No one is this excited to work in the supply rooms.

Fields.DialogueText: Nadürlich - of course!
I always approach work enthusiastically.
Just wait and see, Kapitän.
I haven't had many chances to help out on board, but figured this would be a great opportunity.
"Great" might be too strong a word, but I appreciate your willingness to lend a hand all the same.
Kapitän! We have Nixen approaching!
Everyone to your stations!
@BATTLE
Now, Nürnberg, I know you were initially enthusiastic over the prospect of helping out on board, but as you can see, the equipment room needs a lot of work.
Nürnberg?

Fields.MenuText: Why are you smiling that widely?
Are you quite all right?
I'm going to be honest - you're looking a little deranged, there.

Fields.DialogueText: You're not scared, are you, Kapitän?
Oh, I'm more than all right.
Not the first time I've been told that.
I'm sure much of the crew would look at this room and see nothing but hours of work in front of them. But me? I see possibilities.
You see possibilities... in the equipment room?
So viele Mögglischkeiden. Just wait, Kapitän, you'll see.
Well, you'll have to wait, because we have Morganas coming this way. But you know what I mean.
@BATTLE
Nürnberg, why are you still working in the equipment room at this hour?
Wait.
Nürnberg, what happened in here!?

Fields.MenuText: Everything's a mess! Y-you are going to pick this up, right?
I expect better from my crew, Nürnberg.
How... just... why...

Fields.DialogueText: Ja, ja, calm down.
I won't just give you better. I'll give you the best.
You're not exactly forming coherent sentences.
In order to properly organize an area, it's important to pull everything out and get to the heart of the problem. A little mess is necessary.
I hardly think this qualifies as a little mess. From where I stand, things look much worse than they did when you arrived.
*ALARM*
Well, then, you're just going to have to put some faith in me and my abilities. Besides, that's the alarm sounding now, isn't it? Looks like we have Nixen to deal with.
What have I gotten myself into?
@BATTLE
Nürnberg, I know you wanted me to put faith in you and your abilities, but...
Ja? But what, Kapitän?
Is... everything all right?

Fields.MenuText: How is this possible? The room looks perfect.
Be honest - how many crew members did you force to help you clean up this mess?
What deal with the devil did you make to take care of this room so quickly?

Fields.DialogueText: I know. It's a thing of wonder, isn't it?
None! This is all my own handiwork, Kapitän.
No deals of the supernatural kind were made, I can assure you.
I told you I saw possibilities. You should have listened to me.
Maybe you should have elaborated on the word "possibilities." Look at this - all the life vests organized by size, the lines all perfectly coiled. Amazing!
Well, if you'd like to put my organizational skills to use elsewhere, I'd be happy to lend a hand.
No! I hate to pull you away from your new, favorite place on board, but we do have Morganas approaching from the southwest.
@BATTLE
Nürnberg, I just left the galley. The way you organized the foodstuffs was nothing short of miraculous. The cooks looked as if they might cry.
Sehr gut. I'm glad I'm getting to help - I love having a mission, some sort of work to do.
I'm happy to hear you say that because the medical staff has expressed interest in overhauling their supply room.

Fields.MenuText: Would you mind helping them?
I told them you would assist them.
And because you find that sort of thing strangely invigorating, I thought you might like to help.

Fields.DialogueText: Nadürlich ned! I can start immediately.
Nadürlich! I'm excited by the prospect already.
You thought correctly!
I'm glad to hear it. I'll send word for them to expect you.
Nürnberg? What are you doing?
Oh, sorry, Kapitän. I was trying to write and pay attention at the same time, but I'm not always the best multitasker.
What are you working on? The book looks old.
It's my Wanderbuch - I keep a record of everywhere I go and everything I do inside. Surely you've seen me writing in it before.
So, what you're saying is that you're just as organized personally as you are in the supply rooms?
Well, well, aren't you funny? Although, that's probably true...
Either way, I'm glad I have you on board. And I'd be interested in hearing some of the tales from your book at some point. I'm sure they would be interesting.
I'd be happy to share some in the future. But right now, there are Morganas headed this way. I'll go sound the alarm.
@BATTLE
Having fun making a mess of the medical supplies, Nürnberg?
It's been nowhere near the catastrophe the equipment room was. At the very least, people aren't exclaiming "Good God!" every time they pass by.
Heh.

Fields.MenuText: Well, I very much appreciate your efforts.
Keep up the very excellent work, Nürnberg.
I'm sure the medical staff is thrilled by the work you're doing.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, I'm glad someone does.
I'm glad you think my work has been excellent.
I wouldn't be so sure.
What does that mean? Oh, have your methods been a little much for the medical staff? Don't worry, I'm sure they'll get used to it eventually. I did, after all.
Ich bin mir ned so sischer. Some of them....
Kapitän, we have Nixen spotted, north of us!
Don't worry, Nürnberg. Everything will be fine.
@BATTLE
Captain?
Oh, how can I help you? The medical supply overhaul proceeding as planned?
I wanted to talk to you about Nürnberg. Maybe it's just because I'm American, but...

Fields.MenuText: Her organizational skills are exceptional, aren't they? I can't wait to see how everything looks once she's done.
Has something happened?
I know she's a handful, but try to bear with her.

Fields.DialogueText: About that, sir...
Something is in the process of happening.
Oh, trust me. We've tried.
She doesn't listen to anyone. I know she's good at what she does, but if we have a difference of opinion, she doesn't take anything we say into consideration.
She's assured she knows the best way of doing everything, and we can't convince her otherwise. She's so narrow-minded...
*ALARM*
That's the alarm. You should head to your station, but don't worry. I'll talk to her.
@BATTLE
Thank you, Captain.
Well, hallo, Kapitän.
Do you ever sleep, Nürnberg?
Heh, not much when I have a job to do. I can't ever seem to rest when I know there's more work to be done.

Fields.MenuText: Where is the rest of the medical staff? Did they... leave you here, by yourself?
I've heard rumblings that your work ethic has proven to be overwhelming.
You might be able to rest more if you didn't drive off the rest of the medical staff.

Fields.DialogueText: Ja. I'm afraid so.
I know those rumblings have been making the rounds...
You're not wrong.
Honestly, I didn't mean to offend the staff. I feel bad that we couldn't come to an understanding concerning how things should be organized.
Kapitän! We have Nixen spotted!
We'll work this out, Nürnberg.
@BATTLE
Of course, Kapitän. I can sort out any sort of mess, especially these unkempt Hexen.
Nürnberg! We have Morganas approaching, but meet me back here afterwards.
Jawohl, Kapitän!
@BATTLE
How can I help you, Kapitän?
After hearing how bad you felt over the situation with the medical staff, I talked to them. They're willing to work things out with you if you're willing to compromise with them.
Well... I appreciate your efforts, Kapitän. And I do still feel bad that the officers and I weren't able to work together. But I'm not going to compromise with them.

Fields.MenuText: ... What?
All right, let me rephrase. You will compromise with the medical officers.
I knew there had to be some drawback to your unparalleled organizational skills.

Fields.DialogueText: You heard me.
Nein. I will not.
There are drawbacks to every situation, Kapitän.
The medical officers, their initial ideas for organizing that room were some of the worst I've ever heard. Slow, inefficient. Why would I consider using such methods?
Because you realize your captain would really appreciate it if peace was kept on this ship between its crew and its resident supernatural being.
I've almost finished organizing the medical supply room. What if I promise that, after it's taken care of, I try to smooth things over with the medical staff?
Well, it's better than nothing, I suppose. But we're really going to have to work on your people skills, Nürnberg.
That's not the first time I've heard that.
Was sacht man dazu? Doesn't the medical supply room look wonderful, Kapitän? Every glass polished, every syringe in its proper place. And finished weeks ahead of time.
Don't tell the medical staff I told you this, Nürnberg, but it looks fantastic. Although...
What?
Do you think the end always justifies the means? That, it doesn't matter how many people you step on, as long as the job is done well?
I know it isn't the most popular notion. But I look at it like this - did I take over and offend some of the staff? Ja.
But, ultimately, I know I'm helping them. Even if I'm not acting exactly how they'd prefer, their medical supplies are now in perfect order.
And it isn't just them I'm benefitting, but the crew in general. The next time someone needs medical attention, the staff will know exactly where to find what they need.

Fields.MenuText: It's possible you could have learned something from them if you had been more open to their ideas.

Fields.DialogueText: Genau genomme, anything is possible. But that's a discussion for another time. We have Morganas coming within range.
All right, Nürnberg.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: You got the job done. That's what matters right now.
The crew matters the most. Take care of their needs, not just your need for perfection.

Fields.DialogueText: Proper medical readiness directly addresses their care, Kapitän. I do not understand your problem.
Ja, Kapitän! Unless you are being sarcastic with me...
And?
And nothing. Think about it on your own time - we have Morganas to deal with right now.
This, too, I will execute to the best of my abilities, Kapitän.
Let's see what we have here...
Hmmm...
Oh, that's a lost cause.

Fields.MenuText: What? These potatoes don't look that bad.
I know, this meat does look bad. At least, I think it's meat.
I don't care what you say. I've convinced myself the filling in this pie is cherry, and that's good enough for me.

Fields.DialogueText: No, not the food. Nürnberg, over there. Trying to make nice with the medical staff.
No, not the food. Nürnberg, over there. Trying to make nice with the medical staff.
No, not the food. Nürnberg, over there. Trying to make nice with the medical staff.
I've never seen so many set jaws and cold shoulders. I tried to warn her...
Tell me, Nürnberg... Your conversation with the medical staff didn't go so well, did it?
I did try. But every time I'm around them, they only seem to get angrier. I suppose my people skills have left something to be desired for a while now.

Fields.MenuText: They could probably use a little improvement.
For the good of the crew, that's probably something you should work on.
You think?

Fields.DialogueText: Ja. I know.
Ja. You're probably right.
Don't be unprofessional with a Walküre like me, Kapitän.
But you said they've left something to be desired for a while now. What does that mean?
I... used to get along better with others. At least, I think that was the case. Before the war began. It was a gradual change, I'm not even sure how it happened.
Kapitän, we have Nixen headed this way.
All right. Better get to your station, Nürnberg.
Jawohl, Kapitän. Oh, and Kapitän?
Yes?
There's a storm headed this way, from the west. The crew should prepare the ship.
@BATTLE
Allmächd!
You weren't kidding about this storm, Nürnberg! It's one of the worst I've seen!
Nein, nein, nein, nein, nein...

Fields.MenuText: What's wrong? Are you all right?
Pull yourself together, Nürnberg. What's going on?
What are those wet, dripping papers in your hands?

Fields.DialogueText: Nein, I'm not all right!
Don't tell me to pull myself together!
I can't believe I was so stupid!
I left mein Wanderbuch outside! The spine was already weak, and the wind and rain caused it to break. I was only able to find these pages. The rest flew all over!
Oh, no, I'm sorry, Nürnberg. Here, lay down the pages you have so they can dry.
Kapitän, I think there are Nixen out there! I'll sound the alarm!
We'll tend to these pages as soon we're done - all right, Nürnberg?
All right, Kapitän... and danke.
@BATTLE
Let's put our backs into it!
You understand that there are other people on board who could help you open a stuck door, right?
That thought passed through my head about five seconds after I asked you. Everything's just been so hectic since the storm passed.

Fields.MenuText: Oh, don't worry about it too much.
You really should think before you speak next time.
It's all right. This will just be my upper body exercise for the day.

Fields.DialogueText: I really do appreciate the help, Kapitän.
Yes, of course, Kapitän.
Ha, if you say so, Kapitän.
I think I almost have it open...
There it goes! Thanks so much, Kapitän.
That's a lot of boxes... what is all of this?
Paperwork. Fortunately, most of it looks as if it's still dry. Although, what's that page on the floor? The one by your feet?
It's... well, well, well, that's interesting.
What?
I know this handwriting. It belongs to...
Kapitän! We have Nixen headed this way. You'd better get ready!
@BATTLE
Nürnberg, I have a small surprise for you.
What? This paper...?
Oh, Allmächd - Kapitän, where did you find this?!

Fields.MenuText: I'll give you five guesses. No, twenty. No, you know, I just don't think you'll figure it out. It was in a closet.
In a closet.
In a place that begins with a "c" and ends with a "loset".

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you for not making me guess.
A closet? How peculiar.
Har, aren't you funny?
This is the last page I wrote in mein Wanderbuch. Do you know what this means?
That you really should have found a better bookbinder?
You're a real pain sometimes, you know that? Although, actually, you're probably right... which is beside the point!
All right, then, what's the point?
The point is that I wasn't in my corporeal form when the pages scattered. So there's a possibility that some of them phased through the ship walls and are stuck.
And, you know, it would really mean a lot to me if you would help me look for them. I've been so disappointed in myself ever since I lost them...
Well, at least I now know you're unafraid of using sympathy to get what you want.
So, you'll help?
Well, I figure us searching comes with the added benefit of keeping you away from the medical staff for a while. Maybe that will help them cool off.
Wundervoll! We'll start just as soon as we deal with the Nixen headed our way.
@BATTLE
The galley is always a little creepy when no one else is here, isn't it?

Fields.MenuText: Creepy? It's not creepy. Why would you say it's creepy? I definitely don't think it's creepy. No, not creepy.
Were I to find something creepy, it would have to be more frightening than an empty galley.
Haven't you heard the story of the headless chef who roams the mess hall at night, searching for the hat he'll never be able to use?

Fields.DialogueText: You sound so self-assured, Kapitän.
Well, you're no fun.
You're a strange one sometimes, Kapitän.
Well, look what I found here, underneath the counter.
Ah, another page! Ich lag falsch - you're amazing.
So, since I'm helping you search for your lost pages, does that mean I get to finally hear some of what you've written?
Okay. Es macht mir nichts aus - although I'm afraid you might be disappointed if you've been building up anticipation for a while now.
Let's see... ah, here we are. I've been getting my thoughts down as best I can remember from before I awakened. This came from just before the war began.
"More and more I see the people of Germany united. And that gives me confidence. Confidence in us as a nation, confidence in our hope for the future."
"I find this confidence dispelling any lingering doubts. With this confidence, I have no fear of what's coming. This is the right path. The only right path."
You sound pretty, um... confident in Hitler's vision for the future.
What's not to be assured about? Now, there are Morganas headed this way. We should see to it.
@BATTLE
Kapitän!
Kapitän! Up here!
Kapitän, I could really use your help for a moment!

Fields.MenuText: How in the world did you get up there, Nürnberg?
You really aren't supposed to be up there, Nürnberg.
Oh, no, I just want to wait here and watch you try to get down.

Fields.DialogueText: Not easily or gracefully.
I'll keep that in mind next time, Kapitän.
I dare you to say that again once my feet are back on the ground.
I thought there might be a page up here - I was right, by the way - but it turns out my climbing skills might be better than my descending skills. If you'd just...
Nürnberg, can't you float?
Huh? Oh, ha, you're right, aren't you? Sometimes I spend so much time in my corporeal form, I forget about that entirely. Danke, Kapitän.
*ALARM*
Unbelievable. There's the alarm, why don't you float on down to your post?
No need for that tone, Kapitän. It isn't as if I made you climb up for the page.
@BATTLE
How's the page collection going, Nürnberg?
I've been finding more and more - underneath mattresses, inside empty bottles of cleaner, hiding inside other books.
These pages are quite the sneaky devils.

Fields.MenuText: Well, I certainly applaud your exploratory abilities.
I assume, somewhere, in amongst all the searching, you've found time to see to your duties on board.
Inside empty bottles of cleaner?

Fields.DialogueText: Danke! I love a challenge.
Nadürlich! You know I'm the soul of responsibility.
Don't struggle trying to understand the intricacies of my world and my ship, Kapitän. You should just accept it for what it is.
What was written on your most recent page?
Hmm... ah, this is a good entry, an earlier one than the last. "I heard something new today. My mind hasn't stopped racing, trying to comprehend the possibilities."
"The ideas are radical - some worryingly so. But the potential - the chance these ideas would give Germany, well... how could I turn my back on them?"
It was an exciting time, hearing of Volksgemeinschaft for the first time, the prospect of a united German people. My world was turned upside down by it.
You mean, you heard an entirely new view and accepted it? If you told the medical staff that, I'm not sure they'd believe you.
What was that, Kapitän? Sorry, I missed it. There are Nixen approaching - I'll go sound the alarm.
@BATTLE
Hmm...
Any other places to search coming to mind, Nürnberg?
We've scoured so much of the ship, I'm not sure of many other places we could search.

Fields.MenuText: What about the engine room?
You should probably check the wardroom next.
The rummage is next on my list.

Fields.DialogueText: I had the officers check there yesterday.
No, I checked there earlier, remember?
Well, you can cross it off - I checked earlier today.
Oh, have you looked in your trousers' pockets?
Oh, you're very funny, Nürnberg... wait. How... how in the world did this get in here?
Hahaha, I snuck it in when you weren't paying attention. You should see the look on your face! Wundervoll.
Aren't you the prankster? Here you go. With that page in hand, you have a sizeable Wanderbuch forming.
Something wrong?
Oh, this most recent page. It reminds me of harder times. When I traveled before the war, I remember seeing - sensing - so many people. And the Germans, well - they were having a difficult time.
The Treaty of Versailles caused so much economic turmoil. And I saw it, saw how much they struggled, how little hope they had.
That's why you were so excited by the prospect of German unity? You had seen their hardships and thought that by working together, they could rise above their struggles?
You know, this is a depressing topic, and one I'd really rather not dwell on. I...
Schnell, Kapitän - there are Nixen headed this way!
@BATTLE
Kapitän...
Ah! H-hello there, Nürnberg.
I don't remember saying you could read my Wanderbuch, Kapitän.

Fields.MenuText: Sorry, you caught me.
I wasn't reading. The book was left open, and I was just passing by.
Considering the amount of time I've devoted to helping you find these pages, I'd think I'd be entitled to read a page or two by now.

Fields.DialogueText: I don't really mind, I just like giving you grief.
Sure, Kapitän. I believe you.
"Entitled" might be too strong a term, but you have been a great help.
Something does perplex me, however.
Was, Kapitän?
These earliest pages, from before. There's an openness I don't see in later entries. Here, even - while you're... asleep... you're contemplating different philosophies, without rejecting any of them.
It was a different time. I think we were all different before the war started... before we could see it for ourselves. Anyway, there are Nixen headed this way. I'll head to my post.
@BATTLE
Here it is, my completed Wanderbuch!
Isn't it a sight for sore eyes?
I did the binding myself this time, so we shouldn't have any more unfortunate incidents.

Fields.MenuText: Honestly, I can't believe we found every page. What are the chances?
Now, both of us can return to our duties on board.
Considering some of the places we found pages, I'm surprised the book doesn't smell more than it does.

Fields.DialogueText: Es ist aweng ein Wunder. I'm just so relieved.
You're such a thrill to be around sometimes, Kapitän.
It is boasting a few new odors, that's for certain.
What do you think I should do with it now? I was thinking the crew might find it interesting, although they can be a little careless when it comes to books.
Nürnberg, wait, you're missing a page.
Nein. I'm not.
Yes, you are. Look, it starts on page two.
O-oh, the first page? It didn't have any of my recollections. It's not important.
You... what? You don't want the first page?
I said it isn't important.
Kapitän, we have Nixen inbound.
Thank you, Officer. Well... all right then, Nürnberg. We should be on our way.
@BATTLE
C'mon...
Where could it have ended up?
Kapitän, what are you doing, poking around in that cabinet?

Fields.MenuText: Just trying to find my favorite pen.
Is that really any of your business, Nürnberg?
An admiral is visiting and I'm looking for a place to hide.

Fields.DialogueText: I think I saw it back on your desk.
I suppose not.
That is a joke, right?
Can I help you with something?
N-nein, I was just saying hello. It's just that, I don't know... you're acting a little odd.
*ALARM*
Oh, that's the alarm sounding, isn't it?
Ja... I guess I'll go get into position.
Phew, that was close.
@BATTLE
You've been acting strange recently, Kapitän.
Strange? Me? How so? I don't know what you're talking about.
Ja, you do. Now, tell me what you've been up to.
Fine... I've been trying to find the first page of your Wanderbuch.
Allmächd... What did I tell you about that? I told you it wasn't important!

Fields.MenuText: That's a strong reaction.
Careful with your tone, Nürnberg.
I think there's something on that page that you don't care to see.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, I think it's called for.
I'll watch my tone when you respect what's mine.
That's of no consequence to you.
That page is my own. Mine. It's none of your concern, so leave it alone.
I just don't understand...
Nixen are coming. After we're done with them, I don't want to discuss this again.
@BATTLE
That is not your decision to make, Nürnberg. Nürnberg, are you listening? *sigh*
Thanks for your help with the training exercises earlier today, Officer.
Yes, Kapitän. By the way, that frame on your wall is crooked. See there?

Fields.MenuText: Is it? Ah, just a bit... Don't trouble yourself - I've got this.

Fields.DialogueText: This frame never stays straight, I might have to... wait. What's this, behind it?
Oh, you have to be kidding me. It's the first page of Nürnberg's book. And there's barely anything on it, even. A quote... Oh. Good grief.
Sorry to bother you again, Kapitän, but we have Nixen headed this way.
Thank you, Officer. You're dismissed.
This is sure to go over well.
@BATTLE
Of course, sir. I'll be on my way.

Fields.MenuText: Thanks for pointing that out.
I, um... I keep it that way on purpose.

Fields.DialogueText: Just trying to help, Kapitän. I didn't mean to imply anything...
That will be all.
It's your ship, Kapitän. Just stuck out to me, is all.
Nürnberg?
Ja, Kapitän? Oh, you'll be happy to hear this. One of the medical officers finally talked to me today. I mean, she only replied in monosyllabic answers, but that's an improvement!
I have something to tell you, but I don't think you'll be very happy with me.
Was? What is it?
It was, honestly, a complete accident. But I found the first page of your Wanderbuch.
Unglaublich. You're unbelievable, you know that?

Fields.MenuText: What I did wasn't wrong, Nürnberg. It was in my cabin.
This is my ship. I have the authority to look for what I want on my ship.
Like it or not, someone was bound to find it eventually.

Fields.DialogueText: Make whatever excuse you want. It wasn't right.
How convenient. Next I suppose you'll have opinions about my dress, my hair, my morals... Shall I continue?
Sure, justify your actions. Go for it.
Give it to me, bitte.
Here, it's yours. But what it says, that quote...
There are Nixen coming. You'd better go take care of it, don't you think?
Snap out of it. Let's get battle stations, Nürnberg.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Are you doing all right, Nürnberg? You've seemed somewhat scarce, recently.
You... read what was on the first page?
Yeah. I have to say, a Mark Twain quote wasn't what I was expecting.
"Travel is fatal to prejudice, bigotry, and narrow-mindedness..." I hadn't looked at it in ages, but when you pointed out that it was missing, well... I didn't want to think about it.
When I awoke, I set to reading everything I could get my hands on. That quote was the first thing I wrote in mein Wanderbuch. I thought I would live by those words as I traveled.
But I think... I think there's the possibility that... the person who I was then might not entirely like the person I've become.
You think you were more open-minded while you were asleep... while you were traveling, before the war?
Oh, I know that I was.
So, where does that leave you now?
Ich bin ned so sischer. Thinking, perhaps. But I wanted to say...
Yes?
I'm sorry for the way I reacted. And thank you, for looking for the page.
Thinking is a good thing, after all, and something that... perhaps... I've avoided recently. At least, as far as certain areas of life are concerned.
You're going to be all right?
Am I going to be all right? Of course. Now, there are Morganas headed this way. I say we go deal with it. What do you say?
Sounds good to me.
That is one complicated girl.

Fields.MenuText: I hope she learns to trust me more, moving forward.
And in spite of that, I think I might have... feelings, for her.
